noun.description: A contrapuntal composition in which a short melody or phrase (the subject) is introduced by one part and successively taken up by others and developed by interweaving the parts.
A state or period of loss of awareness of one's identity, often coupled with flight from one's usual environment, associated with certain forms of hysteria and epilepsy.

origin: Late 16th century: from French, or from Italian fuga, from Latin fuga flight, related to fugere flee.
